body_content.explanation: to control a group of people, a country, or a situation:
examples: I think we've chosen the right person to lead the expedition.
I've asked Gemma to lead the discussion.
Who will be leading the inquiry into the accident?

body_content.explanation: (especially in sports or other competitions) to be in front, to be first, or to be winning:
examples: After 30 minutes the challengers were leading by two goals.
With two laps to go Ngomo led by less than two seconds.
The Lions are leading the Hawks 28–9.

body_content.explanation: to cause someone to do something, especially something bad:
examples: The brochure led me to believe that the price included home delivery.
It's worrying that such a prominent politician is so easily led.
He was a weak man, led astray by ambition.

body_content.explanation: to show the way to a group of people, animals, vehicles, etc. by going in front of them:
examples: I don't know the way, so you'd better lead.
If you lead in the jeep, we'll follow behind on the horses.

body_content.explanation: To lead a group of moving people or vehicles is to walk or drive in front of them:
examples: The local youth band will lead the parade this weekend.
A large black hearse led the funeral procession.

body_content.explanation: to take someone somewhere, by going with them:
examples: She led them down the hall.
The waiter led us to our table.
Our guide led us through the mountains.

body_content.explanation: to take hold of a person or animal and take him, her, or it somewhere:
examples: She took the child by the hand and led him upstairs to bed.
He led the horse out of the stable.

body_content.explanation: to show the way by going in front:
examples: You've been there before - why don't you lead the way?

body_content.explanation: to make more progress than other people in the development of something:
examples: The company has been leading the way in network applications for several years.

body_content.explanation: (especially of roads, paths, doors, signs, information, etc.) to go in a particular direction or have a particular result, or to allow or cause this:
examples: There's a track that leads directly to the reservoir.
The door leads out onto a wide, shady terrace.
A narrow trail of blood led directly into the cave.
This information led the police to a house near the harbour.

body_content.explanation: to live a particular type of life:
examples: He was able to lead a normal life, despite the illness.

body_content.explanation: in sports and activities, to move forward first with a particular part of your body, especially as a habit:
examples: You can lead with your left or right leg, depending on which feels more comfortable.
He was booked for leading with his elbow (= running into an opposing football player and hitting them with an elbow).

body_content.explanation: in boxing, to make a first attacking punch (= hit), especially with a particular hand:
examples: They're used to fighting against boxers who lead with their right.

body_content.explanation: a winning position during a race or other situation where people are competing:
examples: For the first time in the race Harrison is in the lead.
With a final burst of speed she went/moved into the lead.
After last night's win Johnson has taken (over) the lead in the championship table.
By the end of the day's play Davies had a lead of three points.

body_content.explanation: the act of showing a person or group of people what to do:
examples: We'll go through the dance routine again - follow my lead (= do what I do).

body_content.explanation: a piece of information that allows a discovery to be made or a solution to be found:
examples: A lead from an informer enabled the police to make several arrests.

body_content.explanation: the main part or actor in a film or play:
examples: Who's been cast as the lead?
Meryl Streep was the lead in that year's Oscar-winning film.

body_content.explanation: a wire covered in plastic and used to connect electrical equipment to the electricity supply
a piece of rope, chain, etc. tied to an animal, especially to a dog at its collar when taking it for a walk:
examples: Please keep your dog on a lead when on the beach.

body_content.explanation: in boxing, a first attacking punch (= hit) by a fighter :
examples: A right-hand lead by Haye caught Ruiz on the chin.

body_content.explanation: used to describe the main performer or part in a performance:
examples: Who played the lead role in the movie?
The lead guitarist was good.

body_content.explanation: a chemical element that is a very heavy, soft, dark grey, poisonous metal, used especially in the past on roofs and for pipes and also for protection against radiation:
examples: lead pipes

body_content.explanation: (the narrow strip of) coloured material, usually black and made of graphite, in the centre of a pencil
